title: In vivo Nanopool: Pooled sgRNA competition assays to evaluate in vivo cancer dependencies
title_html: In vivo Nanopool: Pooled sgRNA competition assays to evaluate in vivo cancer dependencies

protocol.title: In vivo Nanopool: Pooled sgRNA competition assays to evaluate in vivo cancer dependencies
protocol.title_html: In vivo Nanopool: Pooled sgRNA competition assays to evaluate in vivo cancer dependencies

source.description:
Choose dependent cell lines using the
Cancer Dependency Map portal
. Search the literature to determine whether the cell lines proliferate subcutaenously in vivo.
Plate and infect cell lines of interest to assess Cas9 expression.
Infect with 100µL Cas9 nuclease lentivirus and add 4µg/mL polybrene. Add RPMI with 10% FBS (R10) to a final volume of 2mL.
Plate 400,000 cells per well in 6-well plate.

Lift cells the next day and split into two 6-well plates per cell line. Select one with R10 + 10µg/mL blasticidin (10B). We use high concentrations of blasticidin to select for high levels of expression of the integrated transgenes.

Calculate infection efficiency by lifting all cells, counting live cells with a ViCell Coulter counter, and dividing counts in plus puro (selected) by minus puro wells. No Infection Control (NIC, 0µL virus) should be close to zero to pass quality control check.
Expand selected (plus puro) cells and maintain 10B in media. Also expand unselected NIC as a negative control.
Collect pellets from both conditions and rinse twice in cold PBS. Run a western to confirm robust Cas9 expression. As Cas9 is a large protein, it transfers best by wet transfer protocols.

Expand Cas9-expressing cells for in vivo model development in potential dependent cell lines. The exact cell counts will vary according to cell line growth rate. Standard subcutaneous tumor sizes are 4-10 million cells per 100-200 µL injected.
Initiate 2 subcutaneous tumors bilaterally per mouse at variable tumor sizes. Record mouse weight and tumor size every 3 days.
Euthenize mice at humane endpoint. Note tumor latency and initial cell count that leads to tumor growth for 3-4 weeks.
Choose cell line with strong dependency, expression of Cas9, and robust in vivo growth kinetics to carry forward to next steps.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Design library of single guide RNAs (sgRNA). See "Guidelines" section for library considerations.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Prepare plasmid for each sgRNA and accurately quantify DNA concentration following midi- or maxiprep. Accurate quantification of the plasmid virus is essential to achieve equal representation in the pool. We recommend using fluorescent DNA quantification (like Qubit Broad Range Assay) instead of UV-based spectroscopy (like NanoDrop).

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Prepare lentivirus in arrayed format using HEK293T cells. Pool to generate about 75mL of virus. Freeze down 4 x 10mL aliquots for future in vivo experiment and the rest in 1mL aliquots at -80C.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Quality control and titrate the pooled virus by infecting cell line of interest.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Thaw one aliquot to infect one 6-well plate per cell line of interest with a range of viral titers along with 4µg/mL polybrene. Aim for 500x representation, or 500 cells per guide, to ensure adequate representation. We suggest 0µL, 25µL, 50µL, 100µL, 500µL of pooled virus.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: The next day, split each well into 2 equivalent wells of a plus selection and minus selection 6-well plate. Add RPMI + 2µg/mL puromycin to plus selection plate, normal RPMI to the other.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: After two days, calculate infection efficiency by lifting all cells, dividing cell counts in plus puro (selected) by minus puro wells. Determine the viral titer at which infection efficiency is 30-50%. At these infection percentages, each cell is likely infected with only one sgRNA. Pellet two or more replicates of cells at 500 times the number of guides in the pool.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Extract gDNA from cell lines using QIAGEN DNA Mini Kit.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: PCR-amplify 250 ng (100ng minimum - 10µg maximum) gDNA in a 100µL reaction. Lower concentrations of gDNA will benefit from additional cycles, up to 32. P5 and P7 primers amplify barcode regions for Illumina sequencing.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Per reaction, assemble the following on ice: 10µL 10x reaction buffer, 8µL dNTP, 0.5µL P5 primer and P7 primer (100µM), 1.5µL Takara ExTaq polymerase (Clontech). Up to 100µL with water.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Run PCR with following thermocycler conditions: (i) 95°C for 1 minute, (ii) 95°C for 30s, (iii) 58°C for 30s, (iv) 72°C for 30s. (v) Repeat steps ii-iv for 28 cycles. (vi) 72°C, 10 minutes, (vii) 4°C hold.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: For troubleshooting, try a range of annealing temperatures 54-62°C, more cycles, or a range of input gDNA concentrations.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Run 10µL of 100µL PCR product on DNA gel to confirm amplification. Visualize by agarose gel electrophoresis, looking for crisp single band of about 400 nucleotides.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Clean up PCR products with QIAGEN PCR Purification kit, elute into 50µL water or EB.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Submit DNA for CRISPR Illumina sequencing.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Analyze data from read counts.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Extract read counts from Fastq files using open source MaGECK software.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: Analyze representation of each guide in the pool, checking for representation of about 50% negative control guides, 20% positive controls, and 30% experimental guides. This will prevent excessive tumor regression early in the in vivo arm.

source.title: Generate and quality control small library of guides

source.description: If the library passes this quality control check, proceed to the next section with the infected cell line of interest.

Spinfect cells following Broad's
standard protocol
. This puromycin optimization step requires about 30 million cells of interest, confirmed to be mycoplasma-free. Puromycin concentration optimization is designed to minimize time in tissue culture before inoculation, as the constitutive CRISPR/Cas9 system will start cutting DNA immediately upon infection with lentiviral guides.

After expansion and spinfection in 6-well plates, add 2mL R10 plus 0µg/mL (0P), 4µg/mL (4P), or 8µg/mL (8P) puromycin on top of existing 2mL R10. A total of five 6-well plates will be necessary from spinfection for 3 0P control plates harvested at 24, 48, and 72 hours from selection.

After 24 hours, visually inspect plates. When selection is complete, lift and assess infection efficiency by comparing cells counts of 2P and 4P to minus puro condition. Overselection is likely if infection efficiency is much lower for higher concentrations of puromycin at constant viral titer. Aim for the viral titer and puromycin concentration that confers 30-50% infection efficiency.

Calculate how many cells need to be infected to have enough for in vitro/in vivo experiments at this infection efficiency.
Infection efficiency and desired cell count will be known (for example, 7 million x 10 tumors + 30 million for in vitro = 100 million cells). Solve for total initial cells.
Expand cell line of interest expressing Cas9 to "total initial cells" value calculated above.
Lift and pool all cells together. Concentrate or dilute into 200 mL of media, along with 100µL polybrene and titrated amount of virus from 10.3. We typically use about 20mL pooled virus.
Distribute 3 million cells/2mL media in each well of 12-well plates (about four plates for 150 million cells) for infection.
Spinfect for 2 hours at 931g.
After spin, add 2 mL R10 and incubate for 4-6 hours.
Distribute into maximum-volume flasks or plates. For example, 30 x 15cm plates of 5 million cells and 12 mL media.

Add selection reagent at optimized concentration. To avoid disturbing cells, we add 3x concentrated stock, dissolved in medium, to the cells. For example, adding 6 mL of R10 + 18 ug/mL puromycin to 12 mL of medium yields 18mL media at a final concentration of 3 ug/mL.
After 24 hours, start early time point pellet (ETP) collection, in vitro plating, and in vivo inoculation.
Trypsinize and pool all cells together. Accurately count the number of cells via duplicate measurements using the Vicell.
Freeze two cell pellets of 1000x sgRNA representation for downstream determination of the “initial representation” of each sgRNA.

Using standard tissue culture seeding densities, etc., passage duplicate “in vitro screens” at 1000x sgRNA representation, typically two T125 flasks.
Passage as needed and collect timepoints at days 7 and 14 from infection. For this in vitro arm, use plain R10 without antibiotics to mimic lack of selection markers in vivo.

Pellet 10 x desired cells/tumor from model development experiments. Should be in the range of 5-10 million cells. For example, 10 million cells per xenograft for slow-growing cell lines would require 100 million cells.
Resuspend in 500µL R10. Add 500µL matrigel. Keep 10 x 100µL aliquots on ice.
On the same day, inoculate mice with bilateral subcutaneous tumors.
Check isoflurane levels and charcoal. Set up anaesthesia for tank and nose cone in vivarium procedure room.
Anaesthetize mice. One at a time, transfer mice to the nose cone in the hood and check depth of consciousness with a toe pinch.
Moving quickly, vortex cell/matrigel suspension and draw 100µL into syringe. Be careful to avoid bubbles and keep the cell/matrigel suspensions cold.
Inject on mouse flank, keeping bevel of the needle up and lifting skin with forceps to create a pocket. Repeat on opposite flank.
After injection, transfer mouse back to cage. Ensure mouse returns to alert and active consciousness.
Repeat for each of the 5 mice.
Complete health checks and tumor measurements every 3 days.
Visually check health of the mice.
Weigh mice with scale, record on ‘tumor-tracking’ spreadsheet.
Measure width and length of tumors consistently using calipers.
To capture maximum guide dropout, collect in vitro pellets (2 x 7 million cells) on days 7 and 14. Time points should be adjusted for dependencies that confer viability effects at a different rate.
On days 14, 21 and 28, harvest tumors from randomly selected mouse and collect in vitro pellets:
Transfer all mice except the mouse to be sacked into a new cage.
Sack mouse in home cage using CO2, verify with cervical dislocation.
Harvest both tumours, removing as much skin as possible. Dispose of carcass appropriately.
Weigh and wash tumors in PBS.
Flash freeze tissue sample in Liquid N2 until ready to isolate genomic DNA for sequencing.
Homogenize all tumor tissue samples by mincing then lysing overnight in ATL buffer
Repeat steps 11-13 to extract gDNA from each tissue and pellet sample using QIAGEN DNEasy Blood and Tissue kit, amplify barcode, and submit samples fro sequencing.
Repeat steps 14-15 to submit samples then use MAGeCK to extract read counts from Fastq files.
Suggested normalization steps to determine maximum efficacy/acceptable leakiness include:
Normalize read counts to total “mapped” counts.
Assess leakiness by normalizing “no dox” to early time point counts.
Assess efficacy by normalizing “dox” to “dox” negative control counts at each time point.

materials.name: Taq DNA Polymerase with Standard Taq Buffer - 400 units
QIAgen DNeasy Blood and Tissue Kit, 50 rxn
Illumina P5 and P7 primers 5uM combined; P5: 5’ AATGATACGGCGACCACCGAGATCT P7: 5’ CAAGCAGAAGACGGCATACGAGAT
Fetal Bovine Serum, qualified, heat inactivated, USDA-approved regions

description: sgRNA competition assays with constitutive Cas9 systems allow for rapid de-risking of targets in a more representative in vivo microenvironment. Though not a full in vivo validation, the assay is useful as an “invalidation” strategy to discern artifacts of in vitro cultre from promising bona fide targets. This document describes a protocol to select an appropriate cell line, design and generate an sgRNA library for targets of interest, and perform parallel in vitro/in vivo experiments to assess in vivo dependency of the selected genes.
